title: Revisiting the Dream

author: Henry Kautz, Department of Computer Science, University of Rochester

segmentation: My talk today comes in two parts.
In the first part I'll provide an overview of a few of the recent exciting developments in AI and I'll link these to some of the early ambitions of the field.
In the second part, I'll talk about some of the challenges that the triple AI is facing as an organization, and some of the efforts that we're making to meet those challenges.
So begin with this.
Overview of some recent hire.

Sites and I'd like to thank in advance the researchers whose work I'll be talking about, perhaps misinterpreting and thank you for leaving your research results so easily accessible on the web for me to steal.
I also must apologize in advance to the many equally deserving researchers, perhaps more deserving researchers whose work I do not have time or space to talk about.
So I'd like to begin by going back to a very familiar quote.
In AI circles, knowledge is power.
As we all know, this was spoken by Sir Francis Bacon, noted philosopher, an alchemist in the 16th century.
But it is also closely associated with Ed Feigenbaum who helped create the idea of an expert system.
Well, in recent years there's been a slight modification of this.

Phrase data is power which reflects the rise and the application of large scale machine learning combined with a scientific advances, it's really transforming both the field of AI Commerce and basic science.
So that's my first thing.
Name of big data.

Proposals it was a joint call for proposals for many, many agencies, and they called it the Big data call.
But if you go back just to 2010, that phrase was never used in this sense, but so it's an interesting new way to try to capture this notion.
Now the federal US government has not only been helping fund this.
Surge of work, but has been one of the leaders in actually applying it.

So starting in 2009, the White House Office of Science and Technology created a website, data.gov, which links to associated websites such as health.data.govthepurposeofdata.gov is to increase public access to high value machine readable datasets generated by the executive branch of the federal government.
Now the executive branch for those of you may not know is essentially.

There are 1500 applications, about half developed.
By people in the White House Office of Science and Technology half contributed by the ordinary researchers.
Again, if you're working in AI, I suggest you go start browsing data.gov.
You could be quite inspired by this fertile amount of information.
The other concept.
Think of when we think of big Data.
We often think of the web, and in particular we might think of the semantic web.
The idea is yes, we have these 4500 thousand datasets or or more, but each of them is essentially an item into itself.
And if you want to link two of them together, how do you do it?
They don't have a common schema, they don't have a common ontology.
Well, quite a few years ago, Tim Berners Lee and other people and the World Wide Web Consortium started to talk about the semantic Web.
Let's apply knowledge representation to information on the web to create a more structured way of presenting data so that it can be more easily reasoned with now.

I'd like to briefly describe some work on predicting the spread of disease from social interactions that Adam Sadilek will presenting at this conference tomorrow evening.
Where what we did is took data from New York City, about 16,000,000 tweets over a month came in coming from 630,000 unique users.
Of these, about 4.4 million where geotagged coming from cell phones and we concentrated on these GL trag tweets and trained classifiers to identify tweets about the user having flu symptoms.

We mean you've been Co located within some time window with people who have indicated they are sick on that day.

Kasparov went on to become very interested in this notion of partnering humans and computers.

And in fact 1998 Kasparov and another Grandmaster Topalov had a computer assisted match, where they both had a computer at their side while they were playing that they could consult, so they would think about a move.
And then they could try it out on their laptop to see if there was some response.
They had not been able to see, and Kasparov wrote that this is one of the most fantastic, enjoyable matches of his life.
Some of the best chess he's ever played because.
He wrote we could concentrate on strategic planning instead of spending so much time on calculation.
In 2005 there was a what's called a chess freestyle tournament sponsored by an organization play chess.com by freestyle.
That means there are no rules on what a team could be.
It could be a person, it could be several people.
It could be a computer, it could be computers together with people.
And what was interesting is that the teams of humans plus computers easily beat all of the computer only teams.

An even more surprising from Casper OS perspective is that the winner was a pair of amateur players together with three computers coached by the players, so Kasparov himself was again defeated, but this time Kasparov had a computer.
But here we have amateur players with the computer, but these amateur players they also had some understanding of the kinds of algorithms the computer players.
We're using and then could use them very efficiently and have them search in just the right cases.
So this gives us sort of a ranking.
Of power, we have the expert.
Who was defeated by the computer who could be easily defeated by an expert plus a computer who could be defeated by the crowd plus the computer.
